nodes.text: Intergenerational income mobility in the United States varies substantially across local areas and this geographic variation is systematically associated with observable local factors

Method: Construct population-wide child-parent linked sample from deidentified U.S. federal tax records covering ~40 million children and their parents (1996–2012), with primary 'core' sample children born 1980–1982

Method: Measure parent family income as mean family pre-tax income 1996–2000, child family income as mean family pre-tax income 2011–2012 (children ~30), assign child's location by parents' ZIP at age 16 and aggregate to commuting zone (CZ)

Result: Rank-rank relationship (child percentile rank vs parent percentile rank) is almost perfectly linear nationally; estimated rank-rank slope = 0.341 (a 10 percentile increase in parent rank -> 3.41 percentile increase in child rank)

Claim/Measurement: The canonical log-log intergenerational elasticity (IGE) is unstable in these data due to nonlinearity and treatment of zero incomes, so rank-based measures are preferred for robustness and cross-area comparison
Result: National quintile transition matrix implies 7.5% probability of rising from bottom parental quintile to top child quintile; comparable figures for Canada and Denmark are higher (about 11–13%)

Result: Large spatial variation across commuting zones: e.g., probability of bottom-to-top quintile ranges from 4.4% (Charlotte) to 12.9% (San Jose); absolute upward mobility r25 (predicted child rank at parent p=25) among 50 largest CZs ranges from 35.8 (Charlotte) to 46.2 (Salt Lake City)

Result: Rank-rank relationship is approximately linear within CZs and summarized by intercept and slope; slope measures relative mobility, intercept+25*slope measures absolute upward mobility at parent percentile 25 (r25)

Result: Absolute and relative mobility are strongly correlated across CZs (unweighted correlation about -0.68; high relative mobility tends to imply better absolute outcomes for low-income children), with effect concentrated below roughly the 85th parent percentile (pivot point)

Evidence: Geographic variation in intermediate outcomes (college attendance, college quality, teenage birth rates) mirrors spatial variation in income mobility; gradients with parent rank are linear and CZ-level differences appear before labormarket entry

Claim: Five CZ-level factors are strongly correlated with lower upward mobility: (i) greater residential segregation (especially segregation of the poor), (ii) greater inequality among the bottom 99% (higher bottom-99 Gini; middle-class shrinkage), (iii) worse K–12 performance net of parent income (lower test scores/higher dropout), (iv) lower social capital, and (v) weaker family structure (higher share of single-parent families)

Evidence: Correlations and multivariate regressions — segregation (Theil index) and income segregation negatively correlate with r25; segregation of poverty stronger than segregation of affluence; bottom-99 Gini and smaller middle class strongly negatively correlated with r25; school output measures, social capital index, and fraction single-parent children each show strong correlations with r25

Conclusion: Geographic differences in upward mobility are sizable and robust to many alternative specifications (income definitions, price adjustments, growth controls); they are associated with multiple correlates (segregation, bottom-tail inequality, school quality, social capital, family stability) and are not fully explained by racial composition alone
